Name: 1625 First Slaves
Caption: 1625: First slaves brought to New Amsterdam
Description: Date that the Dutch West India Company first brings slaves to what is now New York City
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1635 African Burial Ground is Active
Caption: 1635: African Burial Ground is First Active
Description: Estimated date when free and enslaved African descendents begin burying their dead in an area outside city limits due to laws prohibiting them from burying in what was then the city's primary cemetery
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1653 Slaves ordered to build Wall Street fortification
Caption: 1653: Governor Peter Stuyvesant orders slaves to help build Wall Street fortification
Description: Date that Govenor Peter Stuyvesant orders slaves to assist in the construction of Wall Street fortification
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1664 New Amsterdam becomes New York
Caption: 1664: New Amsterdam becomes New York
Description: Date that New Amsterdam becomes New York
Citation: History.com Editors. “New Amsterdam Becomes New York.” HISTORY, 2 Sept. 2020, https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/new-amsterdam-becomes-new-york. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1673 Van Borsum family takes control of African Burial Ground plot
Caption: 1673: Van Borsum family takes control of plot with restrictions
Description: Date that the burial ground plot is taken under ownership of Van Borsum family, who allow burials but also place restrictions on them—when to bury, how many can attend—in addition to slaves needing written permission to travel to the site from where they were housed
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1692 Beginning of Commons
Caption: 1692: The Commons is first recorded to be in use
Description: Date of when the Commons is earliest in use
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 1. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013. Zotero, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1555.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1735 First Almshouse Built
Caption: 1735: First Almshouse is built and used until 1797, when it's demolished for construction of City Hall
Description: Date of the First Almshouse
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1556.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1741 Conspiracy
Caption: 1741: Conspiracy of 1741
Description: Date of a grave abuse of power by the local government and judiciary
Citation: Sutherland, Claudia. “New York Slave Conspiracy (1741).” BlackPast.org, 6 Mar. 2007, https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/new-york-slave-conspiracy-1741/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021. AND PBS. “Witchhunt in New York: The 1741 Rebellion.” Africans in America, https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part1/1p286.html. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1757 Barracks Built
Caption: 1757: Barracks are built on the Commons for the British Army
Description: Date barracks are built on the Commons for the British Army, who arrived en masse in 1756 and were being quartered in people's houses until the Common Council approved building barracks
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1556.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1759 New Gaol Built
Caption: 1759: New Gaol is built on the Commons as debtor's prison; it also holds prisoners of war during French and Indian War
Description: Date New Goal is built on the Commons as well as its purposes
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1556.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1775 Bridewell Prison Built
Caption: 1775: Bridewell opens to help with overflow of prisoners from New Gaol; also houses American prisoners of war during Revolution
Description: Date Bridewell is built on the Commons as well as its purposes
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1556.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1783 Evacuation Day
Caption: 1783: Last British troops leave Manhattan on November 25
Description: Date of Evacuation Day, when the last British troops left New York, which used to be a major holiday in New York City
Citation: Margino, Megan. “Evacuation Day: New York’s Former November Holiday.” The New York Public Library, 24 Nov. 2014, https://www.nypl.org/blog/2014/11/24/evacuation-day-new-york-holiday. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1793 First Health Department
Caption: 1793: First city health department created
Description: Date of the creation of the first health department for the city, created in response to the outbreak of yellow fever in Philadelphia
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018, https://www.mcny.org/story/germ-city-epidemics-throughout-new-yorks-history. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York

Name: 1794 Van Borsum family ceases ownership of African Burial Ground plot
Caption: 1794: Van Borsum ceases ownership of plot
Description: Date that the Van Borsum ceased owning the burial ground
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1795: plot is subdivided and sold for house lots / First Yellow Fever Cases in NYC
Caption: 1795: Plot is subdivided and sold for house lots / First cases of yellow fever in city; dozens die
Description: Date that the land encompassing the burial ground is sold for house lots / Date of the first cases of yellow fever in New York City
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021. / Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.
Institution: National Park Service / Untapped New York

Name: 1796 Second Almshouse Built
Caption: 1796: Second Almshouse is built to replace first one and remains in use until 1816
Description: Date Second Almshouse is built and in use
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013, http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1556.pdf. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1798 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1798: 800 people die from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1805 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1805: 270 people die from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1812 City Hall Completed
Caption: 1812: Construction of City Hall is completed, atop the former site of the First Almshouse
Description: Date that City Hall is completed, built where the First Almshouse used to be on the Commons
Citation: NYC Design Commission. “About City Hall: Architectural History.” NYC.Gov, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/designcommission/public-programs/city-hall/architectural-history.page. Accessed 1 Apr. 2021.

Name: 1822 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1822: 388 people die from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Crain, Esther. “A Yellow Fever Outbreak Made Greenwich Village.” Ephemeral New York, 6 Apr. 2020, https://ephemeralnewyork.wordpress.com/2020/04/06/a-yellow-fever-outbreak-made-greenwich-village/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1823 Burial Ban
Caption: 1823: New burials below Canal Street are banned
Description: Date of first significant burial ban
Citation: Hedstrom, Casey. “The Manhattan Burial Crisis of 1822 Makes Every Cemetery Today Seem Amazing.” Atlas Obscura, 22 Oct. 2015, http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/the-manhattan-burial-crisis-of-1822-makes-every-cemetery-today-seem-amazing. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1832 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1832: First cholera outbreak kills more than 3,500 people
Description: Date of first cholera outbreak and death toll
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018, https://www.mcny.org/story/germ-city-epidemics-throughout-new-yorks-history. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021. AND Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Name: 1834 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1834: 1,000 more people die from Cholera

Name: 1839 Burial Ban
Caption: 1839: New burials below 14th Street are banned

Name: 1842 Croton Aqueduct Finished
Caption: 1842: Croton Aqueduct is finished
Description: Date marks the first time fresh water is steadily and reliably transported to the city
Citation: Friends of the Old Croton Aqueduct. “The Old Croton Aqueduct: An Engineering Marvel.” Friends of the Old Croton Aqueduct, 15 Jan. 2009, https://aqueduct.org/oca-history. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1847 Rural Cemeteries Act
Caption: 1847: Rural Cemeteries Act is passed
Description: Date marks the passage of the Rural Cemeteries Act which encouraged developement of cemeteries in rural areas and led to the creation of the cemetery belt in Queens and Brooklyn
Citation: Williams, Keith. “Why the Brooklyn-Queens Border Is Full of Dead People.” The New York Times, 27 Apr. 2017. NYTimes.com, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/27/nyregion/why-the-brooklyn-queens-border-is-full-of-dead-people.html. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021. AND Cohen, Michelle. “Five Million Dead in Queens: The History of New York City’s ‘Cemetery Belt.’” 6sqft, 28 Apr. 2017, https://www.6sqft.com/five-million-dead-in-queens-new-york-citys-cemetery-belt/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1847-1848 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1847-1848: Typhoid outbreak kills nearly 2,400 New Yorkers
Description: Date of first major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1849 Cholera Death Toll / Pigs Banned

Name: 1864 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1864: Typhoid outbreak kills more than 1,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Caption: 1861-1872: Tweed Courthouse is built atop former site of Second Almshouse
Description: Date of construction of Tweed Courthouse atop former site of Second Almshouse on the Commons

Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1887 Diphtheria Death Toll
Caption: 1887: Diphtheria kills 4,500
Description: Date of major Diphtheria outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1907 Typhoid Mary Identified
Caption: 1907: After being tied to multiple typhoid outbreaks in the wealthy Long Island homes where she cooked, Mary Mallon ("Typhoid Mary") is sent to live in quarantine on North Brother Island until 1910.
Description: Date of identification of Typhoid Mary
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “The Strange Story of Typhoid Mary, Quarantined on North Brother Island.” Untapped New York, 13 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/13/the-strange-story-of-typhoid-mary-quarantined-on-north-brother-island/. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021. AND Carroll, Rory. “Typhoid Mary: The Super-Spreader before the Term Even Existed.” The Guardian, 10 Mar. 2020, http://www.theguardian.com/science/2020/mar/10/typhoid-mary-super-spreader-history. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.
Institution: Untapped New York and The Guardian

Name: 1915 Typhoid Mary Exiled to North Brother Island Permanently
Caption: 1915: Being unable to make a living in other work, Mary Mallon resumes cooking and is tied to more typhoid outbreaks and subsequently forced to live the last 23 years of her life in exile on North Brother Island.
Description: Date of Typhoid Mary being permanently exiled to North Brother Island
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “The Strange Story of Typhoid Mary, Quarantined on North Brother Island.” Untapped New York, 13 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/13/the-strange-story-of-typhoid-mary-quarantined-on-north-brother-island/. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.
Institution: Untapped New York and The Guardian

Name: 1916 Polio Death Toll
Caption: 1916: Polio infects several thousand people, and kills more than 2,000
Description: Date of polio outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/20/12-epidemics-that-plagued-new-york/. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1918 Influenza Death Toll
Caption: 1918: Influenza epidemic kills more than 30,000
Description: Date of influenza epidemic with death toll in New York City
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018, https://www.mcny.org/story/germ-city-epidemics-throughout-new-yorks-history. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York

Name: 1981 AIDS Crisis Begins
Caption: 1981: Doctors begin seeing first cases new disease (AIDS)
Description: Date that doctors first began noticing what has become known as AIDS
Citation: “HIV/AIDS Timeline.” New York City AIDS Memorial, https://www.nycaidsmemorial.org/timeline. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1991 construction begins on federal office building and human remains are uncovered / bodies are transported to DC for study
Caption: 1991: Construction begins on modern day plot and human remains are uncovered / Bodies are transported to DC for analysis at Howard University
Description: Date that construction begins on federal office building located on modern day plot and human remains are uncovered by excavation workers / Date that human remains of 419 women, men, and children are transported to DC for analysis at Howard University which will last for 12 years
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1994 AIDS Death Toll
Caption: 1994: Almost 50,000 New Yorkers have died from AIDS
Description: Date at heigh of AIDS epidemic with death toll
Citation: Murphy, Tim. “7 New Yorkers Remember the Early Days of the AIDS Epidemic.” Intelligencer, 29 May 2014, https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2014/05/memories-aids-new-york.html. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 1999 nine intact burials are uncovered during construction
Caption: 1999: Nine intact burials are uncovered during construction near initial discovery
Description: Date that nine intact burials are discovered on the southern edge of the historic ground during construction of the new sidewalk in front of Tweed Building on Chambers Street
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 2003 bodies and remains are returned to resting place during Rites of Ancestral Return
Caption: 2003: Rites of Ancestral Return
Description: Date that some 10,000 participants of the "Rites of Ancestral Return" aid in the transportation and re-entering of the ancestral remains to rest on the perserved portion of the site (each in a hand-carved wooden coffin from Ghana)
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 2007 ABNM becomes first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York and Americans of African descent
Caption: 2007: African Burial Ground National Monument becomes first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York and Americans of African descent
Description: Date when the African Burial Ground National Monument became the first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York as well as Americans of African descent
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: 2020 COVID-19 Begins
Caption: 2020: First COVID-19 case confirmed in city on March 1
Description: Date of first confirmed COVID-19 case in New York City
Citation: Goldstein, Joseph, and Jesse McKinley. “Coronavirus in N.Y.: Manhattan Woman Is First Confirmed Case in State.” The New York Times, 2 Mar. 2020. NYTimes.com, https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/01/nyregion/new-york-coronvirus-confirmed.html. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.
